Title: Not Specified
Description:
Saigon, Vietnam.

South Vietnam National Police Chief Nguyen Ngoc Loan executes suspected Viet Cong member Nguyen Van Lem, on the second day of the Tet Offensive during the Vietnam War.

On 31 January 1968, the North Vietnamese Army and the Viet Cong launched a large-scale offensive attacking most major cities in South Vietnam simultaneously. The attacks came as a complete surprise for both the South Vietnamese Army and the American Army, as the Vietnamese Lunar New Year holiday of Tet had just begun, and a ceasefire had been announced for the duration of the holiday. Within a day, the streets of Saigon, a presumed safe hold, had turned into a battlefield. It would take the South Vietnamese Army and the American forces two weeks to regain control of the city.

Description: Volunteers enlist to fight for the self-proclaimed Republic of Biafra, against troops of the Nigerian Federal Military Government.

Description: Volleyball.

Title: Not Specified
Description:
Troops of the Warsaw Pact enter Prague to put an end to the Prague Spring.

The Soviet Union feared that Prime Minister Alexander Dubcek's democratic reforms threatened the balance of power in Eastern Europe. Dozens of people were killed and several Czechoslovakian leaders were arrested.

Title: Not Specified
Description: Man in front of his destroyed house in Belice, after a sequence of earthquakes struck the Italian island of Sicily on 14 and 15 January 1968.

Title: Not Specified
Description: A Russian troika, a horse-drawn sled.

Title: Not Specified
Description:
Marathon athlete Mathias Kanda, member the Rhodesian Olympic athletics team, runs against a steam train known as The Gwelo to Selukwe Flyer.

The photo was initiated in collaboration with John Cheffers, the team's Australian coach, to promote the Olympic team. As photo of the month (June 1968) for the Associated Press, the image was distributed world wide.

Despite the multi-racial selection of the Rhodesian Olympic team, Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe) was banned from competition in the 1968 Summer Olympic in Mexico City, because of international protest against apartheid. Rhodesia did not allow black Rhodesians to vote in national elections.

Title: Flames of Protest
Description:
Washington D.C. is on fire, after riots broke out on 4 April 1968, following the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr., leader of the civil rights movement, one day earlier in Memphis, Tennessee.
After a day of arson, looting, and violence, U.S. President Johnson called in the federal troops to assist the District police force to restore order, which came eventually on 8 April. By that time, 12 people had been killed and more than a thousand people had been injured. Some 1,200 buildings had been burned, including more than 900 stores.

Title: Flames of Protest
Description:
Washington D.C. is on fire, after riots broke out on 4 April 1968, following the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr., leader of the civil rights movement, one day earlier in Memphis, Tennessee.
After a day of arson, looting, and violence, U.S. President Johnson called in the federal troops to assist the District police force to restore order, which came eventually on 8 April. By that time, 12 people had been killed and more than a thousand people had been injured. Some 1,200 buildings had been burned, including more than 900 stores.

Title: Not Specified
Description: Clutching his rosary beads, Senator Robert F. Kennedy lies fatally wounded on the floor of the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles, after he was shot by an assailant following his victory speech in the California primary election. Robert Kennedy died early 6 June, after a team of surgeons tried in vain to save his life.

Title: Not Specified
Description: Not Specified

Title: Not Specified
Description:
Dr. Christiaan Barnard checks on his patient, Philip Blaiberg, after his successful heart transplant in Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town.
Blaiberg was the third person to receive a heart transplant, the first open heart transplant was also conducted by Barnard. The 58-year-old dentist received his new heart on 2 January 1968 from Clive Haupt, a 24-year-old textile worker who had died from a stroke on a Cape Town beach the day before. Blaiberg's transplant gained additional media attention because the donor was a black South African. Blaiberg returned home after two months in hospital. He died on 17 August 1969 from heart complications.

Title: Not Specified
Description:
Brian Dobson of the Huddersfiel Giants is held in full flight by Keith Cotton of the Featherstone Rovers during the Rugby League Challenge Cup semi-finals. 

The Featherstone Rovers won the match, and would also win the Challenge Cup finals, which were played against Barrow at Wembley Stadium.

Title: Not Specified
Description:
Dr Christiaan Barnard checks on his patient, Philip Blaiberg, in Groote Schuur Hospital, Cape Town, after a successful open heart transplant.
Blaiberg was the third person to receive a heart transplant, the first open heart transplant was also conducted by Barnard. The 58-year-old dentist received his new heart on 2 January 1968 from Clive Haupt, a 24-year-old textile worker who had died from a stroke on a Cape Town beach the day before. Blaiberg's transplant gained additional media attention because the donor was a black South African. Blaiberg returned home after two months in hospital. He died on 17 August 1969 from heart complications.

Title: Not Specified
Description: U.S. Athlete Bob Beamon (22) sets a new world record of 8.90m (29 ft 2,5 inches) during the long jump competition at the Summer Olympics in Mexico City. He beat the previous record sensationally by 55,25cm. Beamon's jump was not exceeded until 1991, when Mike Powell jumped 8.95m.
